pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button> are the principle organs of the urinary system, and their primary function is the control of solute levels in the blood and other body fluids. In this investigation, you will explore the anatomy of the kidney. Additionally, you will trace the path of blood as it flows through the kidney.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 5 minutes 
Activity 1: Procedure – 20 minutes

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking digital photos
Isopropyl (rubbing) alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant)
Paper towels
Dissect a mammalian <button class='glossary-text'>kidney</button>.
Be able to identify major anatomical structures of the kidney.
Describe the path of blood flow through the kidney.
Discuss the relationship between kidney structure and function.

pageData.text: Humans are usually born with two , but our bodies can function with just one. However, many diseases result in so much damage to both kidneys that dialysis and/or a kidney transplant is necessary. It is estimated that in the U.S. there are more than 120,000 patients waiting for a kidney transplant. Approximately 3,000 people are added to the waitlist each month. The average time a patient waits for a kidney is 3-5 years, depending on the age, health, compatibility, and availability of organs. In 2020, just over 24,000 patients received a kidney transplant, with about two-thirds of the kidneys coming from deceased donors.

Given that the demand for kidney transplants is anticipated to continue growing, is relying on organ donations a sustainable way to fill this need? Some researchers don’t think so and are working on growing kidneys in the lab. Scientists are taking stem cells and growing “minikidneys”. The hope is that someday kidney cells could be used in conjunction with a 3-D printer to create a full-sized kidney that could be transplanted into a patient.

pageData.desc: Three medical professionals in full protective gear are looking at a monitor while conducting surgery on a patient in an operating room.
pageData.altText: Three medical professionals in full protective gear are looking at a monitor while conducting surgery on a patient in an operating room.

pageData.text: The urinary system filters extra water and waste products from the blood to help maintain proper fluid balance inside the body. An elaborate system of tubes and tubules intertwines with arteries and veins within the <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button> to allow for maximum excretion of waste products, such as various salts and proteins. The ureters carry this waste to the bladder, where it is stored until excretion.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Urinary System

pageData.subTitle: Urinary System
pageData.text: Ureters are long, thin tubes that carry from the (where it is produced) to the bladder.The bladder is a muscular sac that stores urine.The urethra is a narrow tube connected to the bladder that removes urine from the body.

labelInfo.labelName: Abdominal aorta (main artery from heart) carries blood from heart to kidneys
Inferior vena cava (main vein to heart) carries filtered blood from kidneys to body

pageData.subTitle: Kidneys
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button> are found in the upper abdomen on each side of the spine. These fist-size organs filter waste products out of the bloodstream and produce <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button>.

pageData.subTitle: Nephrons
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Nephrons</button> contain a network of tubes, veins, and arteries that intertwine to exchange salts, wastes, and fluids to remove them from the bloodstream.

pageData.subTitle: Glomerulus
pageData.text: A <button class='glossary-text'>glomerulus</button> is a small, round pocket within the kidneys that uses concentration gradients to remove nitrogenous waste and salts from the blood vessels that pass through it.

The primary function of the urinary system is , the control of solutes, mostly ions, in the blood and other body fluids. The (see Mammalian Kidney dissection mat) are the principle organs of the urinary system of vertebrate animals. They are two bean-shaped organs that filter the blood, remove waste from it, and produce , which contains waste as well as other substances such as water. Urine leaves the kidneys through the . Both ureters empty into a single that drains through the and out of the body.

The external surface of the kidney is covered in a thin, transparent layer of connective tissue called the renal capsule. Deep to the renal capsule is the renal cortex, and deep to the cortex is the renal medulla. The kidney contains several cone-shaped renal lobes. Each lobe contains a renal pyramid surrounded by renal cortex that projects between the pyramids in structures called .

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A kidney with the structures labeled.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A kidney with the structures labeled.

pageData.text: Blood flows into each through the renal artery (Figure 2) at an indentation called the hilus. The renal artery splits into branches called the . These branch further into . The interlobar arteries pass through the , and branch again forming the that run between the cortex and medulla. These feed into , from which blood enters a capillary network, the glomerulus of the .

pageData.desc: Figure 2: A kidney with the blood vessels labeled.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A kidney with the blood vessels labeled.

pageData.question: Which of the following is the primary function of the urinary system?

options.text: osmoregulation of body fluids
solid waste excretion
blood glucose maintenance
hormone production
defense against and removal of pathogens

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The primary function of the urinary system is to control the solute content of blood and other body fluids, also known as osmoregulation.

pageData.question: The kidneys receive blood from the heart via the renal arteries. From there, the arteries branch into a series of smaller arteries and eventually a network of capillaries. Which of the following best describes the significance of the highly vascular structure of the kidneys?

options.text: The kidneys’ primary function is to regulate solutes in the blood.
The kidneys’ primary function is to deliver nutrients to the bloodstream.
The kidneys’ primary function is to maintain blood hormone levels.
The kidneys’ primary function is to remove cellular debris from lymph vessels.
The kidneys’ primary function is to recycle to the digestive system.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The kidneys are highly vascular to allow them to control solute levels in the blood, which they do by filtering blood and removing from it water and waste.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The urinary system is made up of four major structures that work together in osmoregulation, or the control of solutes in the blood and other body fluids. The two kidneys, which receive blood through a complex network of arteries, filter blood to maintain healthy solute concentrations and remove waste molecules. The liquid waste, or urine, leaves each kidney via a ureter. The two ureters empty into a single urinary bladder that holds the urine until it exits the body through the urethra.

img.alt: Figure 1: A kidney with the structures labeled.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The urinary system is made up of four major structures that work together in osmoregulation, or the control of solutes in the blood and other body fluids. The two kidneys, which receive blood through a complex network of arteries, filter blood to maintain healthy solute concentrations and remove waste molecules. The liquid waste, or urine, leaves each kidney via a ureter. The two ureters empty into a single urinary bladder that holds the urine until it exits the body through the urethra.

img.alt: Figure 1: A kidney with the structures labeled.

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>nephron</button> (Figure 3) is the functional unit of the <button class='glossary-text'>kidney</button>. Each kidney contains over a million nephrons. The nephrons are responsible for blood filtration and <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> production. The nephron is made up of two structures: the glomerulus and a renal tubule. The glomerulus is an aggregation of capillaries surrounded by the <button class='glossary-text'>glomerular capsule (Bowman’s capsule)</button>; together, the glomerulus and its capsule are called the renal corpuscle. The role of the glomerular capsule is to filter out large molecules and cellular material present in the blood.

Blood leaves the glomerulus through the efferent arteriole. The diameter of the <button class='glossary-text'>afferent arteriole</button> is larger than that of the efferent arteriole, creating pressure in the capillaries of the glomerulus. This pressure forces water, salts, glucose, urea, amino acids, and waste products out of the blood capillaries and into the glomerular capsule. Large particles, such as large molecules, plasma proteins, blood cells, and platelets remain in the capillaries as they are too large to pass through the capillary walls; these pass out of the glomerulus via the efferent arteriole. The fluid remaining in the capsule, called <button class='glossary-text'>filtrate</button>, will eventually become urine.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures, and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow
pageData.altText: Figure 3: diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures, and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow

pageData.question: As blood passes through the glomerulus of a nephron, some materials are filtered out of the blood and into the glomerular capsule to eventually become urine. Which of the following is LEAST likely to be found in the glomerular capsule?

options.text: red blood cells
urea
water
amino acids
salt

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The role of the glomerular capsule is to filter out large molecules and cellular material present in the blood as it passes through the glomerulus. Red blood cells are much too large to diffuse across the capillary walls of the glomerulus into the glomerular capsule.

pageData.question: As blood passes through the glomerulus of a nephron, some materials are filtered out of the blood and into the glomerular capsule to eventually become urine. Which of the following is LEAST likely to be found in the glomerular capsule?

options.text: bacteria
uric acid
salt
hydrogen ions
water

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The role of the glomerular capsule is to filter out large molecules and cellular material present in the blood as it passes through the glomerulus. Bacteria cells are much too large to diffuse across the capillary walls of the glomerulus into the glomerular capsule.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: One of the major functions of the nephrons of the kidneys is to filter blood. This happens largely in the renal corpuscle, which is made up of a glomerulus (a collection of capillaries) and its surrounding glomerular capsule. Blood flows into the glomerulus from the afferent arteriole and exits the glomerulus via the efferent arteriole. While flowing through the capillaries of the glomerulus, small molecules in the blood (I.e., water, salt, urea and other waste) diffuse across the capillary walls and into the capsule. The fluid that fills the capsule is called filtrate, which eventually becomes urine. Large molecules and cellular material that cannot diffuse into the capsule remain in the blood and exit the glomerulus via the efferent arteriole.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: One of the major functions of the nephrons of the kidneys is to filter blood. This happens largely in the renal corpuscle, which is made up of a glomerulus (a collection of capillaries) and its surrounding glomerular capsule. Blood flows into the glomerulus from the afferent arteriole and exits the glomerulus via the efferent arteriole. While flowing through the capillaries of the glomerulus, small molecules in the blood (I.e., water, salt, urea and other waste) diffuse across the capillary walls and into the capsule. The fluid that fills the capsule is called filtrate, which eventually becomes urine. Large molecules and cellular material that cannot diffuse into the capsule remain in the blood and exit the glomerulus via the efferent arteriole.

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>filtrate</button> passes into the first segment of the renal tubule, the <button class='glossary-text'>proximal convoluted tubule</button>. Specialized cells in the proximal convoluted tubule selectively reabsorb salts and nutrients from the filtrate and transfer them into the adjacent peritubular capillaries. The <button class='glossary-text'>descending limb of the nephron loop</button>, carrying the filtrate, runs down into the medulla region of the <button class='glossary-text'>kidney</button>. Interestingly, the blood in the surrounding capillaries flows in a direction opposite that of the filtrate in the tubule. The solute concentration in the capillaries and surrounding fluid is higher than in the filtrate, so there is a concentration gradient that causes water to flow out of the filtrate and into the blood within the peritubular capillaries. This gradually concentrates the filtrate. The cells lining the descending limb are permeable to water but not to urea or ions, preventing these substances from moving out of the descending limb and being reabsorbed into the blood as the concentration of the filtrate increases.

The descending limb makes a hairpin turn, reversing its orientation at the <button class='glossary-text'>loop of the nephron (loop of Henle)</button> and becoming the <button class='glossary-text'>ascending limb of the nephron loop</button>, which reenters the cortex. Cells in this limb are impermeable to water, preventing osmosis from diluting the filtrate, but they are permeable to ions. Some of these move out of the filtrate in response to the concentration gradient established by the low external solute concentration. Toward the upper region of the ascending limb, solutes are actively transported out of the filtrate. The filtrate moves from the ascending limb into the <button class='glossary-text'>distal convoluted tubule</button>, where more water is recovered and the solute concentrations are further adjusted.

The filtrate passes from the distal convoluted tubule into the collecting duct, which descends into the medulla. Since the medulla has a high solute concentration, more water is lost from the filtrate to the surrounding tissue via osmosis. Several collecting ducts converge at the apex of the renal pyramid, a region that is called the renal papilla. The collects from the papilla. The , in turn, collects urine from several minor calyces and conveys it into the . From there, it passes out of the kidney and into the .

The blood in the peritubular capillaries and efferent arteriole flows into the <button class='glossary-text'>arcuate veins</button> and from there the <button class='glossary-text'>interlobar veins</button>. The interlobar veins converge at the renal vein, which exits the kidney at the hilus.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the overall purpose of moving filtrate through the many segments of the renal tubules?

options.text: to recover water and adjust the final solute concentration of the resulting urine
to remove as many solutes as possible and create highly concentrated urine
to remove large molecules and cellular material from the filtrate
to reabsorb proteins from the filtrate into the bloodstream
to reduce the blood pressure in the vessels of the kidneys

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: As filtrate moves through the segments of the renal tubule, water is reabsorbed into the bloodstream. Some solutes are also reabsorbed, while other solutes are added to the filtrate, to make sure the body removes only the molecules that need to be excreted.

pageData.question: In several segments of the renal tubule, such as the descending limb of the nephron, water leaves the filtrate by which of the following mechanisms?

options.text: Water moves passively because the surrounding tissue has a higher solute concentration.
Water moves actively using ATP.
Water moves by co-transport with large molecules.
Water moves passively because it is a small molecule.
Water moves actively because of high pressure from surrounding fluids.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Water in the filtrate leaves into the surrounding tissues because these tissues have a higher solute concentration than the filtrate. Water will passively move from areas of high water concentration (low solute concentration) to areas of low water concentration (high solute concentration).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: After filtrate is collected in the glomerular capsule, it moves to the renal tubule, the second major component of a nephron. The renal tubule is made up of several segments. The first segment the filtrate moves through is the proximal convoluted tubule: here, salts and nutrients are selectively reabsorbed back into the surrounding capillaries. The filtrate then continues to the descending limb of the nephron loop: here, the surrounding capillaries and fluids have a higher solute concentration than the filtrate, allowing water to leave the filtrate and become more concentrated. The filtrate then reaches the ascending limb of the nephron loop: here, some solutes are removed from the filtrate either through diffusion or active transport. The filtrate then continues to the distal convoluted tubule: here, more water leaves the filtrate and solute concentrations are further modified. The last segment of the renal tubule is the collecting duct, where even more water is removed from the filtrate before it leaves the kidneys as urine.

img.alt: Figure 3: diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures, and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: After filtrate is collected in the glomerular capsule, it moves to the renal tubule, the second major component of a nephron. The renal tubule is made up of several segments. The first segment the filtrate moves through is the proximal convoluted tubule: here, salts and nutrients are selectively reabsorbed back into the surrounding capillaries. The filtrate then continues to the descending limb of the nephron loop: here, the surrounding capillaries and fluids have a higher solute concentration than the filtrate, allowing water to leave the filtrate and become more concentrated. The filtrate then reaches the ascending limb of the nephron loop: here, some solutes are removed from the filtrate either through diffusion or active transport. The filtrate then continues to the distal convoluted tubule: here, more water leaves the filtrate and solute concentrations are further modified. The last segment of the renal tubule is the collecting duct, where even more water is removed from the filtrate before it leaves the kidneys as urine.

This investigation requires safety goggles, disposable gloves, and a lab apron.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE); safety glasses or goggles, gloves, and lab aprons must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets (SDS) before beginning the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as disinfectant.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:

text: Clean the counter or workspace thoroughly before and after the dissection using isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant).
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
Only perform the dissection on the dissecting tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
Spread the absorbent pad blue-side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.
In general, scissors are used more frequently than the scalpel, especially when care must be taken not to cut too deeply into the specimen.
Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal:

pageData.text: View the following video: Using a Scalpel

text: Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
Always use a sharp blade.
Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.subTitle: Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>
pageData.text: Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution® have found that it is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® specimens does not require specialized ventilation. Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well-ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.

Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and eyes. Do not ingest specimen, especially if you are or may become pregnant.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, you may choose to place it in the plastic storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the opening with a rubber band, tape, or a binder clip. After closing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
Review the background information and activity instructions. Print out the dissection procedure.
Obtain all materials from the lab kit and those that are needed but not supplied.
Place an absorbent pad on the work area, with the absorbent (white) side facing up.
Place a foam dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to contain fluid that spills on the work area.

In Activity 1, you will examine the external structures of the preserved mammalian . You will then divide the kidney longitudinally and examine the internal structures. You will also open the along its length and observe its endothelial lining.

typeBefore.subTitle: Click to view a video showing major features of the kidney

pageData.text: Begin by observing the external features of the <button class='glossary-text'>kidney</button>, as shown on the left side of the front of the dissection mat. (Numbers in parentheses correspond to structures on the dissection mat.) In the following steps you are asked to identify and photograph a number of structures. Each photograph may have multiple structures displayed. Take notes to keep track of which structures are presented in each picture.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
pageData.altText: camera symbol

text: Observe the renal capsule (11), the thin but tough transparent membrane that adheres closely to the surface of the kidney. Remove any adipose (fatty) tissue that may be attached to the capsule.
Locate the hilus (4). This is an indentation where the <button class='glossary-text'>ureter</button> and blood vessels enter and exit the kidney.

Carefully remove excess adipose tissue to observe the ureter (21) more closely. Excess fat may be removed by pulling on the tissue gently with a pair of forceps. Fat should detach easily; use scissors only if necessary. The renal artery (10) and renal vein (20) may be difficult to locate as they were severed close to the hilus when the kidney was removed from the animal.

pageData.text: Using your scalpel, make a lateral, longitudinal cut through the kidney as shown on the right side of the front of the dissection mat. Locate the renal cortex (13) and renal medulla (15). The renal medulla lies deep to the renal cortex. If you have a hand lens, use it to closely observe the appearance of each region.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: The renal medulla consists of numerous conical structures called renal pyramids (18). The base of each pyramid lies next to the renal cortex, while the tip forms a renal papilla (16). Each papilla projects into the renal sinus (19).

Renal pyramids are separated by bands of tissue called <button class='glossary-text'>renal columns</button> (12). Each column begins in the renal cortex and extends through the renal medulla. Examine the texture of this tissue. Columns have a granular texture similar to that of the renal cortex.

Each renal pyramid and adjacent cortical region defines a renal lobe (14). production takes place in the renal lobes. Each renal papilla discharges urine into a cup-shaped  (8). Four or five minor calyces merge to form a  (7).

Major calyces merge to form the  (17), with its wall of thick, fibrous tissue. Using a probe, trace the path of urine from the renal pyramids to the renal pelvis. Notice that the renal pelvis forms the expanded end of the ureter (21).

Using the scalpel, carefully cut one wall of the ureter and extend the incision to the hilus. Using a hand lens (if available), observe the fine ridges on the endothelial lining of the ureter and renal pelvis.

text: Dispose of any excess fluids down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about 30 seconds to dilute the fluids.
Place the specimen in its storage bag and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimen, put the bag into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.
Rinse and carefully air dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your equipment kit.

Sanitize the workspace with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels. If this is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.

pageData.content: Figure 1. The internal structures of the kidney
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A kidney with the structures labeled.

pageData.content: Figure 2. The blood vessels of the kidney
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A kidney with the blood vessels labeled.

pageData.content: Figure 3. The structures of the nephron
pageData.altText: Figure 3: diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures, and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by setting up the work area and dissection the tools. 

In Activity 1, you will need to locate and identify external structures of intact specimen. Then, divide the specimen longitudinally. Next, you will need to locate and identify the internal structures of specimen. Then open and examine the ureter.

data.title: Afferent arterioles
data.content: Feed blood into the glomerulus

data.title: Arcuate arteries
data.content: Run between the cortex and medulla of the kidneys

data.title: Arcuate veins
data.content: Drain blood from the interlobular veins and empty into the interlobar veins.

data.title: Ascending limb of the nephron loop
data.content: Thick ascending limb that drains urine into the distal convoluted tubule

data.title: Descending limb of the nephron loop
data.content: Constitutes the first part of the loop of Henle that is permeable to water

data.title: Distal convoluted tubule
data.content: Lies between the loop of Henle and the non-secretory part of the nephron; concentrates urine

data.title: Filtrate
data.content: Water and solutes filtered from the blood by the kidneys

data.title: Glomerular capsule (Bowman’s capsule)
data.content: The filtration structure that is part of the glomerulus

data.title: Interlobar arteries
data.content: Pass through the renal columns and branch again forming the arcuate arteries

data.title: Interlobar veins
data.content: Veins in the cortex of the kidney that empty into the arcuate veins.

data.title: Kidneys
data.content: The principal organs of the urinary system of vertebrate animals

data.title: Loop of the nephron (loop of Henle)
data.content: Part of the nephron where the descending limb makes a hairpin turn.

data.title: Major calyx
data.content: Collects urine from several minor calyces and conveys it into the renal pelvis

data.title: Minor calyx
data.content: Surrounds the renal papillae of each pyramid and collects urine from that pyramid

data.title: Nephron
data.content: The functional unit of the kidney

data.title: Osmoregulation
data.content: The control of solutes, mostly ions, in the blood and other body fluids

data.title: Proximal convoluted tubule
data.content: The first segment of the renal tubule

data.title: Renal columns
data.content: Allows the cortex to be better anchored; a medullary extension of the renal cortex

data.title: Renal pelvis
data.content: Funnels urine to the ureter

data.title: Segmental arteries
data.content: Branches of the renal artery

data.title: Ureter
data.content: Duct by which urine passes from the kidney to the bladder

data.title: Urethra
data.content: Duct through which urine leaves the body; sperm leaves by this same duct in males

data.title: Urinary bladder
data.content: Temporary storage reservoir for urine

data.title: Urine
data.content: Fluid created by the kidneys that contains waste as well as other substances, such as water
